FeedItems.Title: Announcing SignalR (alpha) for ASP.NET Core 2.0
FeedItems.Summary: Today we are glad to announce an alpha release of SignalR for ASP.NET Core 2.0. This is the first official preview release of a new SignalR that is compatible with ASP.NET Core. It consists of a server component, a .NET client targeting .NET Standard 2.0 and a JavaScript/TypeScript client. Whatâ€™s New? SignalR for ASP.NET Core... Read more

FeedItems.Title: Welcome to the New Blog Template for ASP.NET Developers
FeedItems.Summary: By Juliet Daniel, Lucas Isaza, and Uma Lakshminarayan Have you always wanted to build a blog or other web application but haven’t had the time or educational resources to learn? With our blog template, available in our GitHub repo, you can create your web application fast and effortlessly, and even learn to master the new... Read more

FeedItems.Title: Getting Started with Windows Containers
FeedItems.Summary: Containers provide a way of running an application in a controlled environment, isolated from other applications running on the machine, and from the underlying infrastructure. They are a cost-effective way of abstracting away the machine, ensuring that the application runs in the same conditions, from development, to test, to production. Containers started in Linux, as... Read more

FeedItems.Title: ASP.NET Core 2.0 Features
FeedItems.Summary: Last week we announced the release of ASP.NET Core 2.0 and described some top new features, including Razor Pages, new and updated templates, and Application Insights integration. In this blog post we are going to dig into more details of features in 2.0. This list is not exhaustive or in any particular order, but highlights... Read more

FeedItems.Title: Announcing ASP.NET Core 2.0
FeedItems.Summary: The ASP.NET team is proud to announce general availability of ASP.NET Core 2.0.Â  This release features compatibility with .NET Core 2.0, tooling support in Visual Studio 2017 version 15.3, and the new Razor Pages user-interface design paradigm.Â  For a full list of updates, you can read the release notes and you can check the list... Read more

FeedItems.Title: Development time IIS support for ASP.NET Core Applications
FeedItems.Summary: With a recent update to Visual Studio 2017, we have added support for debugging ASP.NET Core applications against IIS. This blog post will walk you through enabling this feature and setting up your project to use this feature. Getting Started To get started: You need to install Visual Studio 2017 (version 15.3) Preview (it will... Read more

FeedItems.Title: WCF Web Service Reference Provider â€“ Metadata Exchange Endpoint Authentication
FeedItems.Summary: With the recent update to the WCF Service Reference tool in the VS Marketplace, support has been added for downloading metadata for a web service where the metadata exchange (MEX) endpoint has been secured with IIS authentication. The purpose of MEX endpoints is to allow clients to discover the service capabilities, including security aspects of... Read more

FeedItems.Title: Introducing ASP.NET Core 2.0 Preview 2
FeedItems.Summary: At Build 2017, we released an initial preview version of ASP.NET Core 2.0.Â  Over the last two months we have incorporated your feedback and added a number of new features.Â  We now have a Preview 2 version of the ASP.NET Core 2.0 framework and Visual Studio tools for you to try.Â  In this post, we... Read more

FeedItems.Title: Announcing ASP.NET Core 2.0.0-Preview1 and Updates for .NET Web Developers
FeedItems.Summary: The ASP.NET team is pleased to share the first preview version of the ASP.NET Core 2.0 framework.Â  In this post, weâ€™ll look at the new features and changes to the web framework that were announced at the Build 2017 keynote and sessions.Â  We will also look at some other updates that were published for ASP.NET... Read more

FeedItems.Title: Visual Studio 2017 Tools for Azure Functions
FeedItems.Summary: Visual Studio 2017 Tools for Azure Functions are now available as part of the Azure development workload starting in the Visual Studio 2017 15.3Â release. These tools: Enable creating pre-compiled C# functions that bring better cold start performance than script based functions, and opens the entire eco-system of Visual Studio tools for class libraries including code... Read more

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.PathString.StartsWithSegments returns false unexpectedly" (#2221) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I encountered a strange behavior of `PathString.StartsWithSegments` method.
For the url "/api/_security/login_forms" `Path.StartsWithSegments("/api/")` return `false`.
I believe it's bug, please confirm. 

from Immediate Window (request is `HttpRequest`):
```
request.Path.Value
"/api/_security/login_forms"

request.Path.StartsWithSegments("/api/")
false

request.Path.Value.StartsWith("/api/")
true

request.Path.Value["/api/".Length]
95 '_'
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "CallbackPath on Oauth Authentication cannot specify HTTPS or HTTP protocol" (#2219) at aspnet/Home
Opened issue "CallbackPath on Oauth Authentication cannot specify HTTPS or HTTP protocol" (#2219) at aspnet/Home
Opened issue "Health Checks" (#2218) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi, 

I am wondering what is happening / the current status of the health checks.
The code was here, then it moved to another repo. According to the docs,
we are meant to clone the repo, copy code into our projects to make use of it.

This is less than ideal, as a nuget package would most certainly be first prize.
Also no active development can be seen on that repository which is unnerving.
Is it perhaps that their is no active development because its already perfect? If so,
then why cant a nuget package be released, even if it was a preview release?

Also if it is part of Asp.Net Core, why does the repo not live here with all the other ones?

The roadmap mentions this as part of 2.0 if I am not mistaken, so just wondering about that too. If it was missed and is going to form part of the 2.1 release, I am thinking that at least some work would have been on it by now, even if it was bringing the projects up to date with the latest released bits, the current host dependency is sitting at 1.0.2. There is also not much love given to pull requests, that do not seem all that complicated to provide an accept / reject answer on, I can of course be wrong. Its just how it looks when looking at the repo.

Just a few questions for those who cannot copy source code of what may or may not be what is actually going to land. One can work with preview packages and feel slightly better about it, I think. So any insight or feedback will be greatly appreciated.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "JS client may not give an error if sending an HTTP request fails" (#976) at aspnet/SignalR
Events.RelatedBody:
See: https://github.com/aspnet/SignalR/issues/957#issuecomment-333652247

In ReactNative the client was not able to connect to the server at all and the Error message was empty because both `status` and `statusCode` were `undefined`. It appears however that XmlHttpRequest contains a useful error message which we should include in the Error.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "HubConnection onClosed event not fired on JS client" (#974) at aspnet/SignalR
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm writing a reconnect code to keep alive the hub connection. I was using @aspnet/signalr-client 1.0.0-alpha2-27049 and it was working. Somehow the HubConnection onClosed event was called several times (once every minute 4 times) and then the connection seemed to get stable.

With the new versions of the js client (1.0.0-alpha2-27146 to 1.0.0-alpha2-27174) onClosed event is not being fired. I keep the browser inactive for some minutes, then when I try to make an invoke on the HubConnection I get the next error:

```
Uncaught (in promise) Error: Cannot send data if the connection is not in the 'Connected' State
    at HttpConnection.send (HttpConnection.js:98)
    at Promise (HubConnection.js:168)
    at new Promise (<anonymous>)
    at HubConnection.invoke (HubConnection.js:152)
    at Channel.componentDidUpdate (Channel.js:432)
    at measureLifeCyclePerf (ReactCompositeComponent.js:73)
    at ReactCompositeComponent.js:726
    at CallbackQueue.notifyAll (CallbackQueue.js:74)
    at ReactReconcileTransaction.close (ReactReconcileTransaction.js:78)
    at ReactReconcileTransaction.closeAll (Transaction.js:207)
```

The hub was connected previously as I can see the websocket connected log:
```
Information: WebSocket connected to wss://...
```

The connected state changed to 3 (disconnected) but the onClosed event didn't get called.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "API out-of-the-box ConflictRequestResult " (#6172) at aspnet/Mvc
Events.RelatedBody:
Nice to have, especially for web-api, a **ConflictRequestResult** (409) and a method of Controller (as syntactic sugar).
As others cooked results (BadRequest, Accepted, Created etc.) the  ConflictRequestResult may have some overloads to include enough information for the user/app to recognize the source of the conflict.
Thanks.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add 'global scope' result filters" (#6904) at aspnet/Mvc
Events.RelatedBody:
We have an major design issue - there's no way to register a result filter that runs for **all** results.

Result filters do this thing where they only run on the 'happy path' - you don't get to run for an action result that comes from an exception filter for example.


This breaks down if you want to implement a policy that needs to run for **all** results of a given type. Things we ship in the box that are designed to work with **all** result doesn't do so today - examples: `[Produces]` and `OnResultExecuting` on controllers.

This hasn't come up yet, but imagine you want to implement an exception filter that will short-circuit and return some data to be serialized for an API client. Well this won't take advantage of `[Produces]` today, because that code won't run.

-------------------

I propose we fix this by adding a new interface `IGlobalResultFilter` that derives from `IResultFilter` -  and also `IAsyncGlobalResultResult`. We should also retrofit `[Produces]` with this new interface.

This will work seemlessly on the 'happy path' because the executor will just run these new filters in order with the old ones - they are result filters after all.

The current code in here https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core/Internal/ResourceInvoker.cs#L144 needs to be updated to call `IGlobalResultFilter`s.

Events.RelatedBody:

`<style type="text/css">embed[Height="175"][Width="175"],... `, `<style type="text/css">.ggbox,...`. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13967891/31093082-27f1360e-a776-11e7-8e72-684536d9de12.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Create a VS for Mac Plugin for Razor binaries." (#1696) at aspnet/Razor
Closed issue "Split Microsoft.VisualStudio.LanguageServices.Razor into two assemblies." (#1690) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
We should have a more-generic editor assembly that can be used in VS for mac.

My idea for now is to break the assembly into two:
- `Microsoft.VisualStudio.LanguageServices.Razor`
- `Microsoft.VisualStudio.Editor.Razor` (to correspond with `Microsoft.VisualStudio.Editor`)

Which leaves room for a third assembly for VS for mac specifics: `Microsoft.VisualStudioMac.LangugeServices.Razor`

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Split LanguageServices.Razor." (#1694) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
- Created a new `Microsoft.VisualStudio.Editor.Razor` assembly to contain Visual Studio platform agnostic info.

#1690

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add a VS for Mac compatible Razor addin" (#1701) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
- Add Microsoft.MonoDevelop.RazorAddin.
- As part of this work I also added `Microsoft.MonoDevelop.LanguageServices.Razor` to be the monodevelop specific Razor code.
- Added MSBuild infrastructure to automate creation of MonoDevelop addins (MPacks). This work enables us to not have a dependency on a specific version of monodevelop and does not require us to have tool-prerequisites on the box. Every build outputs the mpacks into the artifacts/build directory.
- Built in build-level metadata pieces to workaround how addins are typically developed. They are usually authored C# first and then config files are generated after the fact; with this changeset we auto-generate the addin.info and its corresponding assembly attributes. Both of these take information directly from the build system.

#1696 

/cc @ToddGrun @KirillOsenkov

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support bound and minimized boolean (or bool?) TagHelper attributes." (#431) at aspnet/Razor
Closed issue "Implementing quirking of parser and language features for Razor" (#1678) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
We're planning some other work items for Razor 2.1.0 that will require us to add features or relax restrictions specific to Razor 2.1.0

The time has come for us to implement version support in Razor. Make it so.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Added version support to Razor parser" (#1683) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
#1678 

@rynowak 

- Added `Version` property to `RazorParserOptions`
- Added an internal `RazorParserFeatureContext` that contains a flag for all features we want to enable/disable in the parser
- Reason for having a centralized location is so we don't have to look at the version every time we want to decide whether to light-up a feature
- ~~I'll send a separate PR that will use `AllowMinimizedBooleanTagHelperAttributes` to enable/disable that feature.~~ https://github.com/aspnet/Razor/pull/1695

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "IEmailSender should have explicitly named parameters for html vs plain text" (#868) at aspnet/Templates
Events.RelatedBody:
There have been a number of people reporting bugs about the email confirmation link in the StarterWeb template not working.

This is happening because people implement IEmailSender and don't realize that the message being passed in is html. When they send the email as plain text the confirmation link does not work because of the url encoding.

I think the "message" parameter of SendEmailAsync should be renamed to htmlMessage and possibly should have an additional parameter for "plainTextMessage" and both should be passed in from AccountController.

This would make it more clear to implementors of IEmailSender what kind of string(s) they are dealing with and how to correctly implement it.

related issues:
https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2152
https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2217

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Cannot update @angular to 4.3.0+ (trying to update to 4.3.6)" (#866) at aspnet/Templates
Events.RelatedBody:
After updating angular to 4.3.6, an internal server error begins to throw "NodeInvocationException: Can't resolve all parameters for HttpXsrfCookieExtractor."

Steps to reproduce:
1. cmd to c:\
2. dotnet --version 
_2.0.0_
3. mkdir dummy
4. cd dummy
5. dotnet new angular
6. dotnet restore
7. npm install
8. dotnet run (prove it works)
8a. ctrl+c to stop the server/build
9. update all @angular from "4.2.5" to "4.3.6"
10. npm update
11. dotnet run
...You should now crash... (see below)
12. change 4.3.6 back to 4.2.5 and 
repeat 10 and 11.
You should now work again.

Please let me know i there's anything else i can provide to help. Thank you!

`NodeInvocationException: Can't resolve all parameters for HttpXsrfCookieExtractor: (?, [object Object], [object Object]).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Cannot update @angular to 4.3.0+ (trying to update to 4.3.6)" (#866) at aspnet/Templates
Events.RelatedBody:
After updating angular to 4.3.6, an internal server error begins to throw "NodeInvocationException: Can't resolve all parameters for HttpXsrfCookieExtractor."

Steps to reproduce:
1. cmd to c:\
2. dotnet --version 
_2.0.0_
3. mkdir dummy
4. cd dummy
5. dotnet new angular
6. dotnet restore
7. npm install
8. dotnet run (prove it works)
8a. ctrl+c to stop the server/build
9. update all @angular from "4.2.5" to "4.3.6"
10. npm update
11. dotnet run
...You should now crash... (see below)
12. change 4.3.6 back to 4.2.5 and 
repeat 10 and 11.
You should now work again.

Please let me know i there's anything else i can provide to help. Thank you!

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "(package.json) Namespaced packages do not display version & details on hover-over" (#829) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
(latest) VStudio 2015 Update **3**

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2574412/19649471/eadc6be0-99d3-11e6-9d8e-565003f9e2cd.png)

When hovering over Namespaced packages (@whatever/), version numbers and details are labeled as "Uknown".

Also intellisense comes out as "Unknown" as well when typing in the version area to the right.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2574412/19649727/e3f93e56-99d4-11e6-81e8-a89cd21abeee.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Having multiple sites with the same IIS Express launch url causes VS to launch the wrong site" (#431) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody: The Security repo has three sample sites with the same launch url. (It needs to be the same because that url is registered with a remote auth server).  This can cause VS / IIS Express to launch the wrong site.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Turn off file nesting in Visual Studio 2017" (#1059) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
To report new issues, use the [Report a Problem](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/) tool. The GitHub Issue Tracker for the aspnet/Tooling repo is now deprecated in favor of the Report a Problem tool.

If you encounter a problem with Visual Studio, we want to know about it so that we can diagnose and fix it. By using the Report a Problem tool, you can collect detailed information about the problem, and send it to Microsoft with just a few button clicks. See [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/talk-to-us) for more details.

To report new issues, use the [Report a Problem](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/) tool. The GitHub Issue Tracker for the aspnet/Tooling repo is now deprecated in favor of the Report a Problem tool.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Model does not serialize to the camelCase by default" (#270) at aspnet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: I am returning a data of the IEnumerable type as a Model of View. And I wait for that a Model has will properties with camelCase formatting as when getting a data from WebApi controller.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Model does not serialize to the camelCase by default" (#270) at aspnet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: I am returning a data of the IEnumerable type as a Model of View. And I wait for that a Model has will properties with camelCase formatting as when getting a data from WebApi controller.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ExpandoObjectAdapter does not assume case insensitivity" (#269) at aspnet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
When applying a json patch to `ExpandoObject`s, case insensitive search will not be used to match the path segment to the object's dictionary keys. Instead, the path segment will be resolved using the `NamingStrategy` defined in the `IContractResolver`.

Addresses https://github.com/aspnet/JsonPatch/issues/102

See https://github.com/aspnet/JsonPatch/issues/103 for discussion
